verses.text: Be merciful to me, O God, for men hotly pursue me; all day long they press their attack.

rsbNotes.title: Ps 56:title
rsbNotes.text: 56:title The title is difficult to fit into David’s life as it is known from the historical books. The closest parallel is 1 Sam. 21:10–15, when David was feigning madness before the king of Gath in order to escape him.

verses.text: My slanderers pursue me all day long; many are attacking me in their pride.
When I am afraid, I will trust in you.
In God, whose word I praise, in God I trust; I will not be afraid. What can mortal man do to me?

rsbNotes.title: Ps 56:2
rsbNotes.text: 56:2 trample on me. The enemies, like ruthless animals, treat the psalmist as their prey.

verses.text: All day long they twist my words; they are always plotting to harm me.
They conspire, they lurk, they watch my steps, eager to take my life.

rsbNotes.title: Ps 56:5
rsbNotes.text: 56:5 injure my cause. They change the meanings of his words (see text note) to put him in a bad light.

verses.text: On no account let them escape; in your anger, O God, bring down the nations.

rsbNotes.title: Ps 56:7
rsbNotes.text: 56:7 cast down the peoples. The parallelism of this verse suggests that the enemies are the foreign nations that surround Israel.

verses.text: Record my lament; list my tears on your scroll - are they not in your record?

rsbNotes.title: Ps 56:8
rsbNotes.text: 56:8 kept count. The psalmist is calling upon God to hear and remember his prayer.

verses.text: Then my enemies will turn back when I call for help. By this I will know that God is for me.
In God, whose word I praise, in the LORD, whose word I praise-
in God I trust; I will not be afraid. What can man do to me?

rsbNotes.title: Ps 56:9
rsbNotes.text: 56:9 This I know. The psalmist remembers God’s covenant promises, such as Deut. 28:7, a promise that God will scatter the enemies of His people.

verses.text: I am under vows to you, O God; I will present my thank offerings to you.
For you have delivered me from death and my feet from stumbling, that I may walk before God in the light of life.

rsbNotes.title: Ps 56:12
rsbNotes.text: 56:12 render thank offerings. When the psalmist’s prayer is answered, he promises to return to offer his thanks. He would do this by offering sacrifices and singing thanksgiving songs similar to Ps. 34. See Ps. 22:22 and note.
